ratings.comment: Tests are MUCH harder then the practice tests with harder MCQ's, more short answer problems, and harder proofs. He did have some nice policies like recording lectures, letting the final replace your lowest test score, and giving info on what would be on the final. Disc wkst's have like 5 useful problems and rest are way too difficult/irrelevant.

The reviews here are a little bit harsh. I thought that he was a solid professor. He did a decent job of teaching the material and made it engaging. It also helps that he posts his lectures for people who weren't in class. That being said, I found that the exams were much harder than the TWO exams from previous years that he gave us to study.

Prof. Keller made Discrete Math make sense. Good lecturer and homeworks are not that hard. Tests are marathons but if you study and do the practice tests and pay attention in class you should be fine.

“”Don't be misled by negative reviews, many seem to come from CS majors, who're kinda clueless about proofs”. That fake review is all you need to know to take it in the fall. This class is called computer sciences 240, take with the CS dept in the fall and save yourself  the headache.

Class is just ok. None of the exams are hard, it's just that if you're like me and make a bunch of stupid mistakes, you're gonna have to try harder on the final. I finished the final in 40 minutes, then spent the next 50 minutes making sure I didn't make stupid mistakes. This class is a cakewalk, just make sure to actually understand the material.

Never posted grade cutoffs, only your letter grade. Tests were graded harshly and were difficult as other people mentioned, lectures and discussions (mandatory) were not that useful. He could probably be a great teacher for most other math classes, but if you're in CS you are better off taking 240 with the CS department in the fall.

The review that he might be making up reviews might actually be true, 5 good reviews within 2 days and 5 people disliking the other reviews is suspicious. Not sure why theres a review about how easy the math in the class is after taking high level proof-based math courses when the class is meant for cs majors with no proof experience.Good lectures.
Just listen in class and review the outlines before the exam and you are all set.
He is a good professor, and lectures are enough to get you through the course.

Definitely wasn't a super easy class, but Dr. Keller did a good job of explaining most of the concepts during lectures. He also provided us with the specific proofs that would appear on the final, which was nice. Only negative is that the grading was a bit harsh and the discussion worksheets were often way harder than anything else we did.

Dr. Keller was excellent and enthusiastic. But, CS240 was too easy. Basic proof techniques took up 4 weeks but could've been covered in 3 days. We barely touched on combinatorics and graph theory. The exams were super easy, even as a freshman. Don't be misled by negative reviews, many seem to come from CS majors, who're kinda clueless about proofs.

Professor Keller is a great lecturer, and I got an A in the class without reading a single page of the Zybook. The homework is not hard, and the exams are fair. If you are willing to work, you will be fine. If you are a math major and have taken a proof class (341, 421, 375) like me before, then the class is going to be a cakewalk.

A horrible class structure, lectures, and a lack of preparation for exams. While I think he wasn't THAT bad as others make him out to be, I believe he isn't suited for anything close to teaching. He would've been a fine/mid professor until his obese/fat personality started to show at the end of the semester.

Answers to questions are often deflected with "check the page," making clarification frustrating. In-class proofs feel rushed, with little real prep for exams. Grading is all-or-nothing on proofs, but support is minimal. You're on your own when it counts.

Pros: Uploads lecture notes and blank copies, provides lots of practice exams, is loud clear when explaining.  

Cons: exams this semester are a lot harder than previous exams or discussion questions, lecture content sometimes differed slightly from what's on hw/discussion (or he simply doesn't cover it), handwriting is a little hard to read (nbd)
His material is messy, and homework grading is very strict

Dr. Keller is a fair professor. Exams are challenging for sure, but you will get out what you put in. He is very approachable during office hours, and is more than willing to help out with written homeworks, etc...  This was his first semester teaching this course so there is likely room for improvement, but overall, I recommend his class.

Terrible professor, terrible tests, terrible grading, AVOID if you can. I don't even know where to start outlining the flaws of his teaching, assignments, and exams. Certainly couldn't fit the qualms into 350 characters maybe more like 3500 characters. Imagine the character of a self-righteous, obese, virtue signaler; that gets you close to Mitch.

Hated how disconnected the exams were from the content taught in the lecture. Much of the lecture's time was spent on useless proofs we would never have to do on an exam. The exams he wrote were also substantially harder than years prior, which caused a fairly low average on all of them.

I am currently taking CS240. Some of the other reviews on here are too harsh. Prof. Keller is a fine teacher. The lectures could definitely be improved but they are not horrible. The weekly assignments are all doable. The class is very test heavy as are the other math classes I have taken here. The textbook is the best resource for the class.

Dr. Keller is a good mathematician, but not a good professor, but the lecture content does not match the content of the exams, the discussion sheets give problems way too hard and the ta's are very nitpicky with the tests and homework. I think half the class is at a C right now.
Highly agree w/ the comment about him coming on here and making up reviews. It's kind of funny how blatant it is actually.

I am taking Discrete Math later than most (last semester of junior year) and just need it for algos. The grading in this is whack, and like other math courses, the discussions are pretty much useless. I am a transfer and my last university didn't have discussions led by TA's who could care less about teaching. Lectures could use a fine tuning also.

Terribly harsh grader, along with his TA's. Do not take Math 240 with him, take cs240 in the fall instead. Lectures aren't too helpful, though they offer good examples of the problems you'll have on hw/exams. Everything on lecture is tested.

I'm convinced that some professors come on here and write reviews of themselves. Dr. Keller is one of them. This is not a personal slight on him, but he has not been that great of a lecturer/professor. Exams make up majority of your grade, and grading is very inconsistent. TA's aren't very helpful, and Dr. Keller isn't very approachable.

I have him for MATH 240 right now. He's a good lecturer, he gives a lot of extra practice for studying, and the exams are easy, but he and his TA's are not good graders. If you don't get the entire question right, then you don't get any points for the question. It sucks, but it makes sense since MATH 240 is a proof-based course, so I can't complain

I really loved my time with Professor Keller in number theory! Classes really encouraged group collaboration, and he was very accessible during office hours for help with the more challenging content. Also very flexible with deadlines! Would take again.

Mitch is a good instructor. However, his grading system is unique. To achieve an A, students must either secure full marks on all assignments and tests or gain extra credit. Without meeting these criteria, the highest possible grade is an AB.

I took calc in high school and struggled, but Dr. Keller is amazing at explaining math concepts and finally made me actually understand calculus. Lectures aren't mandatory, but I would recommend going since ta's will be there if you have questions about in-class problems. As long as you do the homework and discussion problems, you'll be fine!

Professor Keller did a great job of explaining concepts in a clear and engaging way. By giving students time to try problems in class as well as ask questions, he creates a good learning environment. This course is very test heavy (similar to all math courses) so I would recommend that students attend lectures, discussions, and do test prep.

I think he does a good job explaining tougher topics. BUT if you are a person that likes to go to office hours do not go to his. He is not very approachable during office hours and it seems like he couldn't be bothered to help most of the time. Lectures are also recorded so attendance is not necessary.

Professor Keller is great. All his word problems are about "Bob the Iguana," except for one problem, which was about zombies coming for your brain. He read it in a zombie voice to the class, which I respect. Best of all is Dr. Keller's stellar use of canvas. He makes learning math doable for any student that puts in the time and effort.

Tests are literally 85% of your grade. So unfair. If you like a good gpa and aren't a good test taker (like so many people are) DO NOT take this class!!!! Prof isn't the most approachable, and it is impossible to get a good grade in the class if you do poorly on just one exam. Frustrating isn't even the word to describe this class, and professor.
Does not do the best job thoroughly explaining math concepts.
